Award.AwardTitle: Charge transfer, injection and mobility in organic semi-conducting materials: modeling for insight on mechanistic aspects
Award.AbstractNarration:
Barry D. Dunietz at Kent State University is supported in an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program to develop and implement computational models to study electron transfer and transport processes involved in solar-to-electric energy conversion using organic materials. The modeling supports related experimental efforts for synthesizing the materials and fabricating devices with the goal of improving their energy conversion efficiency. The project involves outreach activity that seeks to engage large numbers of high school students in a college-level curriculum and to expose the students to research within the chemistry department. The investigator partners with high schools in the area and collaborates with Kent State University (KSU)-based programs to effectively integrate the young students into the teaching and research activities of the chemistry department.

The Dunietz group develops and implements computational models to study electron transfer and transport (ETT) processes involved in solar-to-electric energy conversion using organic semiconducting materials. The computational approach addresses challenges in modeling charge transfer electronic states and the effects of coupling to the environment such as solvation, binding to electrodes and thenmorphology of organic thin films. The modeling requires the appropriate treatment of the underlying states, the coupling to extended systems, and the reaction kinetics induced by exciton generation. Both density functional theory and time-dependent density functional theory are used as well as molecular dynamics tools for ETT through organic solid crystals. The group investigates related spectroscopic studies and physical measurements to benchmark this approach and to provide mechanistic insight into ETT processes. Ultimately the studies combined with related experimental efforts have the potential to improve organic photo-voltaic applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project outcomes improve our understanding of photoinducedprocesses in organic semiconducting materials.  A computationalapproach to investigate photoinduced processes in the condensed phasewas developed.  The insight gained by the calculations impactsoptoelectronic applications such as of solar energy harvesting basedon organic photovoltaics and of light generation based on organic light emittingdiodes.

The main outcome of the research project includes the development of acomputational framework to treat with a predictive quality thephotoinduced processes at the molecular level.  The approach includesnovel electronic structure approaches addressing the role of themolecular environment, and employing first-principles calculatedexcited state potential energy surfaces in rate theories that gobeyond the semiclassical perspective. Importantly the electronic structure approach addresses consistently the electrostatic environment that is known to affect strongly chargetransfer states.  Furthermore, we implemented our descriptions of thephoto induced dynamics at levels of theory that go beyond thewidely used semiclassical limit.

We studied photoinduced processes in molecular systems includingelectron transfer, emission and phosphorescence activity, photochemistryreactivity, and charge transport.  Our calculations are wellbenchmarked demonstrating predictive quality, and are pursuedalongside relevant experimental efforts including those by our collaborators.

In particular, calculations were implemented to reveal a moleculardesign approach to achieve organic materials that present high chargemobility in their crystal phase. In collaboration with organicsynthesis experts, we elaborate on the ways that fluorination oforganic semiconducting molecular systems can be employed to achievewell packed crystal phase that is also associated with physical properties that enhance the charge mobility.

In another thrust, our calculations elaborated on  photoinduced processes indimers and dyads consisting of bacteriochlorin pigments. Such molecular systems are key to the functionality of natural photosystems transforming absorbed radiation to stored chemical energy. Ourcomputational framework assists the design of nature-inspiredartificial photo harvesting systems by improving the understanding of thecomplex photosystem structure function relationships.

In another thrust of research efforts we investigated a large molecular triad ofcarotene-porphyrin-fullerene to understand the relationship ofconformational flexibility on the charge transfer kinetics.  Thesequential CT process leading to charge separation was shown todominate the transfer mechanism at the energetically stable linearconformation, whereas at the entropically dominant bent conformation  charge separation is hindered.

Modified by: Barry D. Dunietz

  • Selective fluorination of organic semiconducting molecules can enhance attractive intermolecular interactions without increasing the risk for charge trapping.
